title: 109_s2475
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community Act of 2006". It establishes a commission. The Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community Act of 2006 establishes a Commission consisting of 23 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, minority leader of the House, majority leader of the Senate, and minority leader of the Senate. The President appoints 7 voting members, while the Speaker of the House, minority leader of the House, majority leader of the Senate, and minority leader of the Senate each appoint 3 voting members. Additionally, each of them appoints 1 nonvoting member. Members of the Commission must meet certain qualifications. The Speaker of the House, minority leader of the House, majority leader of the Senate, and minority leader of the Senate appoint 1 nonvoting member each. Members of the Commission must have a commitment to American Latino life, art, history, or culture, along with expertise in museum administration. The Commission members must have a commitment to American Latino life, art, history, or culture, along with expertise in museum administration, fundraising, teaching Latino culture, or studying Smithsonian representation. The Commission members must have expertise in fundraising for nonprofit or cultural institutions, teaching Latino culture at the postsecondary level, studying the issue of Smithsonian Institution's representation of American Latino art, or experience in public or elected service. Additionally, they should have experience in museum administration or planning for the establishment of museums focused on ethnic, racial, or cultural groups. The Commission members must have expertise in fundraising for nonprofit or cultural institutions, teaching Latino culture at the postsecondary level, studying the issue of Smithsonian Institution's representation of American Latino art, or experience in public or elected service. Additionally, they should have experience in museum administration or planning for the establishment of museums focused on ethnic, racial, or cultural groups in American history. The Commission's functions are outlined in Section 3. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress with recommendations for establishing and maintaining a National Museum of the American Latino Community in Washington, DC. They will also develop fundraising plans for the Museum and examine issues in consultation with the Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution. The Commission will develop fundraising plans for the National Museum of the American Latino Community in Washington, DC, including contributions from the American people and the Latino community. They will also examine issues such as collection availability, impact on regional museums, and possible locations for the Museum. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress on the availability, cost, impact, possible locations, governance, and organizational structure of the National Museum of the American Latino Community in Washington, DC. The Commission will submit a report on the National Museum of the American Latino Community in Washington, DC, including considerations for location, governance, organizational structure, and community engagement. Legislation will be proposed based on the report for consideration by the Committee on Transportation. Legislation will be proposed by the Commission for consideration by various House and Senate committees based on recommendations from reports on the development and design of the Museum. The Commission will propose legislation for the creation of the Museum based on recommendations from various House and Senate committees. Additionally, a national conference will be convened to gather individuals dedicated to advancing American Latino life, art, history, and culture. SEC. 4. ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS. The Secretary of the Interior provides administrative services, facilities, and funds for the Commission's functions. Commission members not employed by the government receive compensation and travel expenses as determined by the Secretary of the Interior. The Commission must submit final reports, plans, and recommendations within 18 months of the Act's enactment and terminate within 30 days of submission. $2.1 million is authorized for fiscal year 2007 and $1.1 million for fiscal year 2008 for Commission activities.
